Climate change has the potential to disrupt ecosystem services and further exacerbate the effects of human activities on natural resources. This has significant implications for educational institutions and the populations they serve. As the current crop of Landscape Architecture and related students prepare to design future environments, the unknowns of a changing climate cause a significant challenge to their future success. This paper explores the usefulness of a multidisciplinary, flipped classroom, experiential learning approach to teaching students about designing for climate change. The project described here engages students in the co-creation of knowledge in partnership with the community; students explore the past, present, and future of a specific locality to understand the effects of climate change on the ecosystem services of a coastal prairie. Through this process, students gain an understanding of the different ways climate change can impact an ecosystem and how to use design to support the ecosystem services provided by the coastal prairie. This approach helps students understand the complexities of climate change and how to apply their knowledge to create innovative and adaptive solutions.

This article highlights the importance of renewal in higher education to prepare landscape architecture students and faculty to engage the major environmental and social challenges of our time. It builds upon the 2016 Land8x8 Lightning Talks in which the authors participated, seeking to expand the discussion and provide concrete recommendations for improving the discipline's contribution to the creation of resilient communities and regions. The article begins with an analysis of the ways in which landscape architecture programs currently engage climate change and other pressing issues through their curricula and research agendas. It then identifies five strategies for enriching and broadening the conversation: 1) embrace the environmental humanities, 2) incorporate the latest science, 3) expand the geographic and cultural scope of our work, 4) engage other disciplines, and 5) learn from best practices. The article provides specific recommendations for implementing these strategies within individual courses as well as across the curriculum. The conclusion calls on landscape architecture educators to provide leadership on the critical environmental and social challenges of the 21st century, both in our institutions and in the public sphere.

The impacts of climate change are vast in scope and continue to influence the built and natural environment. From a built environment perspective, climate change is increasing the demand for climate change-related infrastructure, including renewable energy infrastructure, new stormwater systems, and urban green infrastructure. Architecture, landscape architecture, and planning students will be asked to provide leadership in the design of such infrastructure, yet few studies have examined how students perceive climate change and its impact on design. To fill this gap, we present survey research from first-year architecture, landscape architecture, and planning students enrolled in a design and planning studio at the University of Washington. Results show that students perceive climate change as relevant to their studies and future careers, yet they are uncertain about how to address it in design. The year that was: 2010

By Sam Smith | 12.31.2010 | 9:30 a.m. CT

It’s been one of those years for the Bulls, one of the best in the last decade. Even though we’re not quite there yet, it’s starting to feel like the 1990’s all over again. We’re not saying the Bulls are going to win six championships, but we are saying that the Bulls are back. It’s been a long time since we’ve been able to say that, and it’s a great feeling.

So as we look back on 2010, it’s hard not to be excited about the future. The Bulls have a young, talented core in Derrick Rose, Joakim Noah and Luol Deng, and they’ve added some key pieces in Carlos Boozer and Kyle Korver. They’re off to a great start this season, and if they can stay healthy, there’s no reason why they can’t make a deep run in the playoffs.

But before we get too far ahead of ourselves, let’s take a look back at some of the highlights of 2010:

— The Bulls finished the 2009-10 season with a 41-41 record, good for eighth place in the Eastern Conference. They lost to the Cleveland Cavaliers in the first round of the playoffs, but they gave the Cavs all they could handle, taking them to six games.

— Derrick Rose was named the NBA’s Rookie of the Year, becoming the first Bulls player to win the award since Michael Jordan in 1985.

— The Bulls made some key additions in the offseason, signing Carlos Boozer, Kyle Korver and Ronnie Brewer.

— The Bulls got off to a great start in the 2010-11 season, winning their first eight games. They’ve been one of the best teams in the league all season, and they’re currently in first place in the Central Division.

— Derrick Rose has been one of the best players in the league this season, and he’s a leading candidate for the MVP award.

So there you have it, a look back at the year that was for the Bulls. It’s been a great year, and we’re excited about what the future holds. Here’s to a great 2011!
